summary.long: 2 Samuel is a book of the Old Testament.

verses.text: After the death of Saul, when David had returned from defeating the Amalekites, David remained two days in Ziklag.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the third day, a man came from Saul’s camp with his clothes torn and dirt on his head. When he came to David, he fell to the ground and did obeisance.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David said to him, “Where have you come from?” He said to him, “I have escaped from the camp of Israel.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David said to him, “How did things go? Tell me!” He answered, “The army fled from the battle, but also many of the army fell and died, and Saul and his son Jonathan also died.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David asked the young man who was reporting to him, “How do you know that Saul and his son Jonathan died?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The young man reporting to him said, “I happened to be on Mount Gilboa, and there was Saul leaning on his spear, while the chariots and the horsemen drew close to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he looked behind him, he saw me and called to me. I answered, ‘Here, sir.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And he said to me, ‘Who are you?’ I answered him, ‘I am an Amalekite.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said to me, ‘Come, stand over me and kill me, for convulsions have seized me, and yet my life still lingers.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So I stood over him and killed him, for I knew that he could not live after he had fallen. I took the crown that was on his head and the armlet that was on his arm, and I have brought them here to my lord.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David took hold of his clothes and tore them, and all the men who were with him did the same.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They mourned and wept and fasted until evening for Saul and for his son Jonathan and for the army of the Lord and for the house of Israel, because they had been struck down by the sword.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David said to the young man who had reported to him, “Where do you come from?” He answered, “I am the son of a resident alien, an Amalekite.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David said to him, “Were you not afraid to lift your hand to destroy the Lord’s anointed?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David called one of the young men and said, “Come here and strike him down.” So he struck him down, and he died.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David said to him, “Your blood be on your head, for your own mouth has testified against you, saying, ‘I have killed the Lord’s anointed.’ ”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David intoned this lamentation over Saul and his son Jonathan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (He ordered that The Song of the Bow be taught to the people of Judah; it is written in the Book of Jashar.) He said,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Your glory, O Israel, lies slain upon your high places!
    How the mighty have fallen!
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
You mountains of Gilboa,
    let there be no dew or rain upon you
    nor bounteous fields!
For there the shield of the mighty was defiled,
    the shield of Saul, anointed with oil no more.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
From the blood of the slain,
    from the fat of the mighty,
the bow of Jonathan did not turn back,
    nor the sword of Saul return empty.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
O daughters of Israel, weep over Saul,
    who clothed you with crimson, in luxury,
    who put ornaments of gold on your apparel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
How the mighty have fallen
    in the midst of the battle!
Jonathan lies slain upon your high places.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
How the mighty have fallen,
    and the weapons of war perished!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After this David inquired of the Lord, “Shall I go up into any of the cities of Judah?” The Lord said to him, “Go up.” David said, “To which shall I go up?” He said, “To Hebron.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David went up there, along with his two wives, Ahinoam of Jezreel and Abigail the widow of Nabal of Carmel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David brought up the men who were with him, every one with his household, and they settled in the towns of Hebron.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then the people of Judah came, and there they anointed David king over the house of Judah.
When they told David, “It was the people of Jabesh-gilead who buried Saul,”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David sent messengers to the people of Jabesh-gilead and said to them, “May you be blessed by the Lord, because you showed this loyalty to Saul your lord and buried him!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now may the Lord show steadfast love and faithfulness to you! And I, too, will reward you because you have done this thing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Therefore let your hands be strong and be valiant, for Saul your lord is dead, and the house of Judah has anointed me king over them.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Abner son of Ner, commander of Saul’s army, had taken Ishbaal son of Saul and brought him over to Mahanaim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He made him king over Gilead, the Ashurites, Jezreel, Ephraim, Benjamin, and all Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ishbaal, Saul’s son, was forty years old when he began to reign over Israel, and he reigned two years. But the house of Judah followed David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The time that David was king in Hebron over the house of Judah was seven years and six months.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abner son of Ner and the servants of Ishbaal son of Saul went out from Mahanaim to Gibeon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joab son of Zeruiah and the servants of David went out and met them at the pool of Gibeon. One group sat on one side of the pool, while the other sat on the other side of the pool.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abner said to Joab, “Let the young men come forward and have a contest before us.” Joab said, “Let them come forward.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they came forward and were counted as they passed by, twelve for Benjamin and Ishbaal son of Saul and twelve of the servants of David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Each grasped his opponent by the head and thrust his sword in his opponent’s side, so they fell down together. Therefore that place was called Helkath-hazzurim, which is at Gibeon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The battle was very fierce that day, and Abner and the men of Israel were beaten by the servants of David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The three sons of Zeruiah were there, Joab, Abishai, and Asahel. Now Asahel was as swift of foot as a wild gazelle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Asahel pursued Abner, turning neither to the right nor to the left as he followed him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Abner looked back and said, “Is it you, Asahel?” He answered, “Yes, it is.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abner said to him, “Turn to your right or to your left, and seize one of the young men, and take his spoil.” But Asahel would not turn away from following him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abner said again to Asahel, “Turn away from following me; why should I strike you to the ground? How then could I show my face to your brother Joab?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But he refused to turn away. So Abner struck him in the stomach with the butt of his spear, so that the spear came out at his back. He fell there and died where he lay. And all those who came to the place where Asahel had fallen and died stood still.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Joab and Abishai pursued Abner. As the sun was going down they came to the hill of Ammah, which lies before Giah on the way to the wilderness of Gibeon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Benjaminites rallied around Abner and formed a single band; they took their stand on the top of a hill.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Abner called to Joab, “Is the sword to keep devouring forever? Do you not know that the end will be bitter? How long will it be before you order your people to turn from the pursuit of their kinsmen?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joab said, “As God lives, if you had not spoken, the people would have continued to pursue their kinsmen, not stopping until morning.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joab sounded the trumpet, and all the people stopped; they no longer pursued Israel or engaged in battle any further.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abner and his men traveled all that night through the Arabah; they crossed the Jordan, and, marching the whole forenoon, they came to Mahanaim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joab returned from the pursuit of Abner, and when he had gathered all the people together, there were missing of David’s servants nineteen men besides Asahel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the servants of David had killed of Benjamin three hundred sixty of Abner’s men.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They took up Asahel and buried him in the tomb of his father, which was at Bethlehem. Joab and his men marched all night, and the day broke upon them at Hebron.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was a long war between the house of Saul and the house of David; David grew stronger and stronger, while the house of Saul became weaker and weaker.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Sons were born to David at Hebron: his firstborn was Amnon, of Ahinoam of Jezreel;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: his second was Chileab, of Abigail the widow of Nabal of Carmel; the third was Absalom son of Maacah, daughter of King Talmai of Geshur;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the fourth was Adonijah son of Haggith; the fifth was Shephatiah son of Abital;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and the sixth was Ithream, of David’s wife Eglah. These were born to David in Hebron.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While there was war between the house of Saul and the house of David, Abner was making himself strong in the house of Saul.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Saul had a concubine whose name was Rizpah daughter of Aiah. And Ishbaal said to Abner, “Why have you gone in to my father’s concubine?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The words of Ishbaal made Abner very angry; he said, “Am I a dog’s head for Judah? Today I keep showing loyalty to the house of your father Saul, to his brothers, and to his friends and have not given you into the hand of David, yet you charge me now with a crime concerning this woman.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So may God do to Abner and so may he add to it! For just what the Lord has sworn to David, that will I accomplish for him:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: to transfer the kingdom from the house of Saul and set up the throne of David over Israel and over Judah, from Dan to Beer-sheba.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And Ishbaal could not answer Abner another word because he feared him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abner sent messengers to David where he was, saying, “To whom does the land belong? Make your covenant with me, and I will give you my support to bring all Israel over to you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said, “Good; I will make a covenant with you. But one thing I require of you: you shall never appear in my presence unless you bring Saul’s daughter Michal when you come to see me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David sent messengers to Saul’s son Ishbaal, saying, “Give me my wife Michal, to whom I became engaged at the price of one hundred foreskins of the Philistines.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ishbaal sent and took her from her husband Paltiel the son of Laish.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But her husband went with her, weeping as he walked behind her all the way to Bahurim. Then Abner said to him, “Go back home!” So he went back.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abner sent word to the elders of Israel, saying, “For some time past you have been seeking David as king over you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now then bring it about, for the Lord has promised David: Through my servant David I will save my people Israel from the hand of the Philistines and from all their enemies.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abner also spoke directly to the Benjaminites; then Abner went to tell David at Hebron all that Israel and the whole house of Benjamin were ready to do.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Abner came with twenty men to David at Hebron, David made a feast for Abner and the men who were with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abner said to David, “Let me go and rally all Israel to my lord the king, in order that they may make a covenant with you and that you may reign over all that your heart desires.” So David dismissed Abner, and he went away in peace.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Just then the servants of David arrived with Joab from a raid, bringing much spoil with them. But Abner was not with David at Hebron, for David had dismissed him, and he had gone away in peace.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Joab and all the army that was with him came, it was told to Joab, “Abner son of Ner came to the king, and he has dismissed him, and he has gone away in peace.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Joab went to the king and said, “What have you done? Abner came to you; why did you dismiss him, so that he got away?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You know that Abner son of Ner came to deceive you and to learn your comings and goings and to learn all that you are doing.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Joab came out from David’s presence, he sent messengers after Abner, and they brought him back from the cistern of Sirah, but David did not know about it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Abner returned to Hebron, Joab took him aside in the gateway to speak with him privately, and there he stabbed him in the stomach. So he died on account of the blood of Asahel, Joab’s brother.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Afterward, when David heard of it, he said, “I and my kingdom are forever guiltless before the Lord for the blood of Abner son of Ner.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: May the bloodguilt fall on the head of Joab and on all his father’s house, and may the house of Joab never be without one who has a discharge, or who has a defiling skin disease, or who holds a spindle, or who falls by the sword, or who lacks food!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Joab and his brother Abishai murdered Abner because he had killed their brother Asahel in the battle at Gibeon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David said to Joab and to all the people who were with him, “Tear your clothes, put on sackcloth, and mourn over Abner.” And King David followed the bier.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They buried Abner at Hebron. The king lifted up his voice and wept at the grave of Abner, and all the people wept.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The king lamented for Abner, saying,
“Should Abner die as a fool dies?
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text: Then all the people came to persuade David to eat something while it was still day, but David swore, saying, “So may God do to me and more, if I taste bread or anything else before the sun goes down!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the people took notice of it, and it pleased them, just as everything the king did pleased all the people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So all the people and all Israel understood that day that the king had no part in the killing of Abner son of Ner.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the king said to his servants, “Do you not know that a prince and a great man has fallen this day in Israel?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Today I am powerless, even though anointed king; these men, the sons of Zeruiah, are too violent for me. The Lord pay back the one who does wickedly in accordance with his wickedness!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Saul’s son Ishbaal heard that Abner had died at Hebron, his courage failed, and all Israel was dismayed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul’s son had two captains of raiding bands; the name of the one was Baanah, and the name of the other was Rechab. They were sons of Rimmon, a Benjaminite from Beeroth, for Beeroth is considered to belong to Benjamin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (Now the people of Beeroth had fled to Gittaim and are there as resident aliens to this day.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul’s son Jonathan had a son who was crippled in his feet. He was five years old when the news about Saul and Jonathan came from Jezreel. His nurse picked him up and fled, and in her haste to flee it happened that he fell and became lame. His name was Mephibosheth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now the sons of Rimmon the Beerothite, Rechab and Baanah, set out, and about the heat of the day they came to the house of Ishbaal while he was taking his noonday rest.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They came inside the house as though to take wheat, and they struck him in the stomach; then Rechab and his brother Baanah escaped.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now they had come into the house while he was lying on his couch in his bedchamber; they attacked him, killed him, and beheaded him. Then they took his head and traveled by way of the Arabah all night long.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They brought the head of Ishbaal to David at Hebron and said to the king, “Here is the head of Ishbaal son of Saul, your enemy who sought your life; the Lord has avenged my lord the king this day on Saul and on his offspring.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David answered Rechab and his brother Baanah, the sons of Rimmon the Beerothite, “As the Lord lives, who has redeemed my life out of every adversity,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: when the one who told me, ‘See, Saul is dead,’ thought he was bringing good news, I seized him and killed him at Ziklag—this was the reward I gave him for his news.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: How much more, then, when wicked men have killed a righteous man on his bed in his own house! And now shall I not require his blood at your hand and destroy you from the earth?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David commanded the young men, and they killed them; they cut off their hands and feet and hung their bodies beside the pool at Hebron. But the head of Ishbaal they took and buried in the tomb of Abner at Hebron.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then all the tribes of Israel came to David at Hebron and said, “Look, we are your bone and flesh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For some time, while Saul was king over us, it was you who led out Israel and brought it in. The Lord said to you, ‘It is you who shall be shepherd of my people Israel, you who shall be ruler over Israel.’ ”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So all the elders of Israel came to the king at Hebron, and King David made a covenant with them at Hebron before the Lord, and they anointed David king over Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David was thirty years old when he began to reign, and he reigned forty years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At Hebron he reigned over Judah seven years and six months, and at Jerusalem he reigned over all Israel and Judah thirty-three years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king and his men marched to Jerusalem against the Jebusites, the inhabitants of the land, who said to David, “You will not come in here; even the blind and the lame will turn you back,” thinking, “David cannot come in here.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nevertheless, David took the stronghold of Zion, which is now the city of David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David had said on that day, “Whoever would strike down the Jebusites, let him get up the water shaft to attack the lame and the blind, those whom David hates.” Therefore it is said, “The blind and the lame shall not come into the house.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David occupied the stronghold and named it the city of David. David built the city all around from the Millo inward.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And David became greater and greater, for the Lord of hosts was with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Hiram of Tyre sent messengers to David, along with cedar trees and carpenters and masons who built David a house.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David then perceived that the Lord had established him king over Israel and that he had exalted his kingdom for the sake of his people Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In Jerusalem, after he came from Hebron, David took more concubines and wives, and more sons and daughters were born to David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These are the names of those who were born to him in Jerusalem: Shammua, Shobab, Nathan, Solomon,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ibhar, Elishua, Nepheg, Japhia,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Elishama, Eliada, and Eliphelet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the Philistines heard that David had been anointed king over Israel, all the Philistines went up in search of David, but David heard about it and went down to the stronghold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now the Philistines had come and spread out in the valley of Rephaim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David inquired of the Lord, “Shall I go up against the Philistines? Will you give them into my hand?” The Lord said to David, “Go up, for I will certainly give the Philistines into your hand.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David came to Baal-perazim, and David defeated them there. He said, “The Lord has burst forth against my enemies before me like a bursting flood.” Therefore that place is called Baal-perazim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Philistines abandoned their idols there, and David and his men carried them away.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Once again the Philistines came up and were spread out in the valley of Rephaim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When David inquired of the Lord, he said, “You shall not go up; go around to their rear and come upon them opposite the balsam trees.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When you hear the sound of marching in the tops of the balsam trees, then be on the alert, for then the Lord has gone out before you to strike down the army of the Philistines.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David did just as the Lord had commanded him, and he struck down the Philistines from Geba all the way to Gezer.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David again gathered all the chosen men of Israel, thirty thousand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David and all the people with him set out and went from Baale-judah to bring up from there the ark of God, which is called by the name of the Lord of hosts who is enthroned on the cherubim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They carried the ark of God on a new cart and brought it out of the house of Abinadab, which was on the hill. Uzzah and Ahio, the sons of Abinadab, were driving the new cart
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: with the ark of God, and Ahio went in front of the ark.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David and all the house of Israel were dancing before the Lord with all their might, with songs and lyres and harps and tambourines and castanets and cymbals.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they came to the threshing floor of Nacon, Uzzah reached out his hand to the ark of God and took hold of it, for the oxen lurched.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The anger of the Lord was kindled against Uzzah, and God struck him there, and he died there beside the ark of God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David was angry because the Lord had burst forth with an outburst upon Uzzah, so that place is called Perez-uzzah to this day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David was afraid of the Lord that day; he said, “How can the ark of the Lord come into my care?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David was unwilling to take the ark of the Lord into his care in the city of David; instead, David took it to the house of Obed-edom the Gittite.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The ark of the Lord remained in the house of Obed-edom the Gittite three months, and the Lord blessed Obed-edom and all his household.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It was told King David, “The Lord has blessed the household of Obed-edom and all that belongs to him because of the ark of God.” So David went and brought up the ark of God from the house of Obed-edom to the city of David with rejoicing,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and when those who bore the ark of the Lord had gone six paces, he sacrificed an ox and a fatted calf.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David danced before the Lord with all his might; David was girded with a linen ephod.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David and all the house of Israel brought up the ark of the Lord with shouting and with the sound of the trumpet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As the ark of the Lord came into the city of David, Michal daughter of Saul looked out of the window and saw King David leaping and dancing before the Lord, and she despised him in her heart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They brought in the ark of the Lord and set it in its place, inside the tent that David had pitched for it, and David offered burnt offerings and offerings of well-being before the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When David had finished offering the burnt offerings and the offerings of well-being, he blessed the people in the name of the Lord of hosts
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and distributed food among all the people, the whole multitude of Israel, both men and women, to each a cake of bread, a portion of meat, and a cake of raisins. Then all the people went back to their homes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David returned to bless his household. But Michal the daughter of Saul came out to meet David and said, “How the king of Israel honored himself today, uncovering himself today before the eyes of his servants’ maids, as any vulgar fellow might shamelessly uncover himself!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David said to Michal, “It was before the Lord, who chose me in place of your father and all his household, to appoint me as prince over Israel, the people of the Lord—I will dance before the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will make myself yet more contemptible than this, and I will be humbled in my own eyes, but by the maids of whom you have spoken, by them I shall be held in honor.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And Michal the daughter of Saul had no child to the day of her death.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now when the king was settled in his house and the Lord had given him rest from all his enemies around him,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the king said to the prophet Nathan, “See now, I am living in a house of cedar, but the ark of God stays in a tent.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nathan said to the king, “Go, do all that you have in mind, for the Lord is with you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But that same night the word of the Lord came to Nathan,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Go and tell my servant David: Thus says the Lord: Are you the one to build me a house to live in?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I have not lived in a house since the day I brought up the people of Israel from Egypt to this day, but I have been moving about in a tent and a tabernacle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Wherever I have moved about among all the people of Israel, did I ever speak a word with any of the tribal leaders of Israel, whom I commanded to shepherd my people Israel, saying, ‘Why have you not built me a house of cedar?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now therefore thus you shall say to my servant David: Thus says the Lord of hosts: I took you from the pasture, from following the sheep to be prince over my people Israel,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and I have been with you wherever you went and have cut off all your enemies from before you, and I will make for you a great name, like the name of the great ones of the earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And I will appoint a place for my people Israel and will plant them, so that they may live in their own place and be disturbed no more, and evildoers shall afflict them no more, as formerly,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: from the time that I appointed judges over my people Israel, and I will give you rest from all your enemies. Moreover, the Lord declares to you that the Lord will make you a house.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When your days are fulfilled and you lie down with your ancestors, I will raise up your offspring after you, who shall come forth from your body, and I will establish his kingdom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He shall build a house for my name, and I will establish the throne of his kingdom forever.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will be a father to him, and he shall be a son to me. When he commits iniquity, I will punish him with a rod such as mortals use, with blows inflicted by human beings.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But I will not take my steadfast love from him, as I took it from Saul, whom I put away from before you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Your house and your kingdom shall be made sure forever before me; your throne shall be established forever.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In accordance with all these words and with all this vision, Nathan spoke to David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then King David went in and sat before the Lord and said, “Who am I, O Lord God, and what is my house, that you have brought me thus far?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And yet this was a small thing in your eyes, O Lord God; you have spoken also of your servant’s house into the distant future. May this be instruction for the people, O Lord God!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And what more can David say to you? For you know your servant, O Lord God!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Because of your promise and according to your own heart, you have wrought all this greatness so that your servant may know it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Therefore you are great, O Lord God, for there is no one like you, and there is no God besides you, according to all that we have heard with our ears.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Who is like your people, like Israel? Is there another nation on earth whose God went to redeem it as a people and to make a name for himself, doing great and awesome things, driving out nations and their gods before your people, whom you redeemed for yourself from Egypt?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And you established your people Israel for yourself to be your people forever, and you, O Lord, became their God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And now, O Lord God, as for the word that you have spoken concerning your servant and concerning his house, confirm it forever; do as you have promised.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Thus your name will be magnified forever in the saying, ‘The Lord of hosts is God over Israel,’ and the house of your servant David will be established before you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For you, O Lord of hosts, the God of Israel, have made this revelation to your servant, saying, ‘I will build you a house’; therefore your servant has found courage to pray this prayer to you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And now, O Lord God, you are God, and your words are true, and you have promised this good thing to your servant;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: now, therefore, may it please you to bless the house of your servant so that it may continue forever before you, for you, O Lord God, have spoken, and with your blessing shall the house of your servant be blessed forever.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Some time afterward, David attacked the Philistines and subdued them; David took Metheg-ammah out of the hand of the Philistines.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He also defeated the Moabites and, making them lie down on the ground, measured them off with a cord; he measured two lengths of cord for those who were to be put to death and one length for those who were to be spared. And the Moabites became servants to David and brought tribute.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David also struck down the king of Zobah, Hadadezer son of Rehob, as he went to restore his monument at the River Euphrates.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David took from him one thousand seven hundred horsemen and twenty thousand foot soldiers. David hamstrung all the chariot horses but left enough for a hundred chariots.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the Arameans of Damascus came to help King Hadadezer of Zobah, David killed twenty-two thousand men of the Arameans.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David put garrisons among the Arameans of Damascus, and the Arameans became servants to David and brought tribute. The Lord gave victory to David wherever he went.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David took the gold shields that were carried by the servants of Hadadezer and brought them to Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: From Betah and from Berothai, towns of Hadadezer, King David took a great amount of bronze.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When King Toi of Hamath heard that David had defeated the whole army of Hadadezer,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Toi sent his son Joram to King David, to greet him and to congratulate him because he had fought against Hadadezer and defeated him. Now Hadadezer had often been at war with Toi. Joram brought with him articles of silver, gold, and bronze;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: these also King David dedicated to the Lord, together with the silver and gold that he dedicated from all the nations he subdued,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: from Edom, Moab, the Ammonites, the Philistines, Amalek, and from the spoil of the king of Zobah, Hadadezer son of Rehob.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David won a name for himself. When he returned, he killed eighteen thousand Edomites in the Valley of Salt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He put garrisons in Edom; throughout all Edom he put garrisons, and all the Edomites became David’s servants. And the Lord gave victory to David wherever he went.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David reigned over all Israel, and David administered justice and equity to all his people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joab son of Zeruiah was over the army; Jehoshaphat son of Ahilud was recorder;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Zadok son of Ahitub and Ahimelech son of Abiathar were priests; Seraiah was secretary;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Benaiah son of Jehoiada was over the Cherethites and the Pelethites; and David’s sons were priests.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David asked, “Is there still anyone left of the house of Saul to whom I may show kindness for Jonathan’s sake?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now there was a servant of the house of Saul whose name was Ziba, and he was summoned to David. The king said to him, “Are you Ziba?” And he said, “At your service!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king said, “Is there anyone remaining of the house of Saul to whom I may show the kindness of God?” Ziba said to the king, “There remains a son of Jonathan; he is crippled in his feet.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king said to him, “Where is he?” Ziba said to the king, “He is in the house of Machir son of Ammiel, at Lo-debar.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then King David sent and brought him from the house of Machir son of Ammiel, at Lo-debar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Mephibosheth son of Jonathan son of Saul came to David and fell on his face and did obeisance. David said, “Mephibosheth!” He answered, “I am your servant.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David said to him, “Do not be afraid, for I will show you kindness for the sake of your father Jonathan; I will restore to you all the land of your grandfather Saul, and you yourself shall eat at my table always.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He did obeisance and said, “What is your servant, that you should look upon a dead dog such as I?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king summoned Saul’s servant Ziba and said to him, “All that belonged to Saul and to all his house I have given to your master’s grandson.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You and your sons and your servants shall till the land for him and shall bring in the produce, so that your master’s grandson may have food to eat, but your master’s grandson Mephibosheth shall always eat at my table.” Now Ziba had fifteen sons and twenty servants.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Ziba said to the king, “According to all that my lord the king commands his servant, so your servant will do.” Mephibosheth ate at David’s table, like one of the king’s sons.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Mephibosheth had a young son whose name was Mica. And all who lived in Ziba’s house became Mephibosheth’s servants.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Mephibosheth lived in Jerusalem, for he always ate at the king’s table. Now he was lame in both his feet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Some time afterward, the king of the Ammonites died, and his son Hanun succeeded him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David said, “I will deal loyally with Hanun son of Nahash, just as his father dealt loyally with me.” So David sent envoys to console him concerning his father. When David’s envoys came into the land of the Ammonites,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the princes of the Ammonites said to their lord Hanun, “Do you really think that David is honoring your father just because he has sent messengers with condolences to you? Has not David sent his envoys to you to search the city, to spy it out, and to overthrow it?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Hanun seized David’s envoys, shaved off half the beard of each, cut off their garments in the middle at their waists, and sent them away.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When David was told, he sent to meet them, for the men were greatly ashamed. The king said, “Remain at Jericho until your beards have grown and then return.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the Ammonites saw that they had become odious to David, the Ammonites sent and hired the Arameans of Beth-rehob and the Arameans of Zobah, twenty thousand foot soldiers, as well as the king of Maacah, one thousand men, and the men of Tob, twelve thousand men.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When David heard of it, he sent Joab and all the army of the warriors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Ammonites came out and drew up in battle array at the entrance of the gate, but the Arameans of Zobah and of Rehob and the men of Tob and Maacah were by themselves in the open country.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Joab saw that the battle was set against him both in front and in the rear, he chose some of the picked men of Israel and arrayed them against the Arameans;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the rest of the troops he put in the charge of his brother Abishai, and he arrayed them against the Ammonites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said, “If the Arameans are too strong for me, then you shall help me, but if the Ammonites are too strong for you, then I will come and help you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Be strong, and let us be courageous for the sake of our people and for the cities of our God, and may the Lord do what seems good to him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Joab and the people who were with him moved forward into battle against the Arameans, and they fled before him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the Ammonites saw that the Arameans fled, they likewise fled before Abishai and entered the city. Then Joab returned from fighting against the Ammonites and came to Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when the Arameans saw that they had been defeated by Israel, they gathered themselves together.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hadadezer sent and brought out the Arameans who were beyond the River, and they came to Helam, with Shobach the commander of the army of Hadadezer at their head.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When it was told David, he gathered all Israel together and crossed the Jordan and came to Helam. The Arameans arrayed themselves against David and fought with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Arameans fled before Israel, and David killed of the Arameans seven hundred chariot teams and forty thousand horsemen and wounded Shobach the commander of their army, so that he died there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When all the kings who were servants of Hadadezer saw that they had been defeated by Israel, they made peace with Israel and became subject to them. So the Arameans were afraid to help the Ammonites any more.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the spring of the year, the time when kings go out to battle, David sent Joab with his officers and all Israel with him; they ravaged the Ammonites and besieged Rabbah. But David remained at Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It happened, late one afternoon when David rose from his couch and was walking about on the roof of the king’s house, that he saw from the roof a woman bathing; the woman was very beautiful.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David sent someone to inquire about the woman. It was reported, “This is Bathsheba daughter of Eliam, the wife of Uriah the Hittite.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David sent messengers to get her, and she came to him, and he lay with her. (Now she was purifying herself after her period.) Then she returned to her house.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The woman conceived, and she sent and told David, “I am pregnant.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David sent word to Joab, “Send me Uriah the Hittite.” And Joab sent Uriah to David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Uriah came to him, David asked how Joab and the people fared and how the war was going.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David said to Uriah, “Go down to your house and wash your feet.” Uriah went out of the king’s house, and there followed him a present from the king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Uriah slept at the entrance of the king’s house with all the servants of his lord and did not go down to his house.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they told David, “Uriah did not go down to his house,” David said to Uriah, “You have just come from a journey. Why did you not go down to your house?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Uriah said to David, “The ark and Israel and Judah remain in booths, and my lord Joab and the servants of my lord are camping in the open field; shall I then go to my house to eat and to drink and to lie with my wife? As you live and as your soul lives, I will not do such a thing.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David said to Uriah, “Remain here today also, and tomorrow I will send you back.” So Uriah remained in Jerusalem that day. On the next day,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David invited him to eat and drink in his presence and made him drunk, and in the evening he went out to lie on his couch with the servants of his lord, but he did not go down to his house.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the morning David wrote a letter to Joab and sent it by the hand of Uriah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the letter he wrote, “Set Uriah in the forefront of the hardest fighting, and then draw back from him, so that he may be struck down and die.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As Joab kept watch over the city, he assigned Uriah to the place where he knew there were valiant warriors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The men of the city came out and fought with Joab, and some of the servants of David among the people fell. Uriah the Hittite was killed as well.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Joab sent and told David all the news about the fighting,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and he instructed the messenger, “When you have finished telling the king all the news about the fighting,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: if the king’s anger rises and if he says to you, ‘Why did you go so near the city to fight? Did you not know that they would shoot from the wall?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Who killed Abimelech son of Jerubbaal? Did not a woman throw an upper millstone on him from the wall, so that he died at Thebez? Why did you go so near the wall?’ then you shall say, ‘Your servant Uriah the Hittite is dead, too.’ ”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the messenger went and came and told David all that Joab had sent him to tell.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The messenger said to David, “The men gained an advantage over us and came out against us in the field, but we drove them back to the entrance of the gate.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the archers shot at your servants from the wall; some of the king’s servants are dead, and your servant Uriah the Hittite is dead also.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David said to the messenger, “Thus you shall say to Joab, ‘Do not let this matter trouble you, for the sword devours now one and now another; press your attack on the city and overthrow it.’ And encourage him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the wife of Uriah heard that her husband was dead, she made lamentation for him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When the mourning was over, David sent and brought her to his house, and she became his wife and bore him a son.
But the thing that David had done displeased the Lord,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and the Lord sent Nathan to David. He came to him and said to him, “There were two men in a certain city, the one rich and the other poor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The rich man had very many flocks and herds,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: but the poor man had nothing but one little ewe lamb that he had bought. He brought it up, and it grew up with him and with his children; it used to eat of his meager fare and drink from his cup and lie in his bosom, and it was like a daughter to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now there came a traveler to the rich man, and he was loath to take one of his own flock or herd to prepare for the wayfarer who had come to him, but he took the poor man’s lamb and prepared that for the guest who had come to him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David’s anger was greatly kindled against the man. He said to Nathan, “As the Lord lives, the man who has done this deserves to die;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: he shall restore the lamb fourfold because he did this thing and because he had no pity.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nathan said to David, “You are the man! Thus says the Lord, the God of Israel: I anointed you king over Israel, and I rescued you from the hand of Saul;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I gave you your master’s house and your master’s wives into your bosom and gave you the house of Israel and of Judah, and if that had been too little, I would have added as much more.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Why have you despised the word of the Lord, to do what is evil in his sight? You have struck down Uriah the Hittite with the sword and have taken his wife to be your wife and have killed him with the sword of the Ammonites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now, therefore, the sword shall never depart from your house, for you have despised me and have taken the wife of Uriah the Hittite to be your wife.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Thus says the Lord: I will raise up trouble against you from within your own house, and I will take your wives before your eyes and give them to your neighbor, and he shall lie with your wives in broad daylight.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For you did it secretly, but I will do this thing before all Israel and in broad daylight.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David said to Nathan, “I have sinned against the Lord.” Nathan said to David, “Now the Lord has put away your sin; you shall not die.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nevertheless, because by this deed you have utterly scorned the Lord, the child born to you shall die.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then Nathan went to his house.
The Lord struck the child whom Uriah’s wife bore to David, and it became very ill.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David therefore pleaded with God for the child; David fasted and went in and lay all night on the ground.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The elders of his house stood beside him urging him to rise from the ground, but he would not, nor did he eat food with them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the seventh day the child died. And the servants of David were afraid to tell him that the child was dead, for they said, “While the child was still alive, we spoke to him, and he did not listen to us; how then can we tell him the child is dead? He may do himself some harm.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when David saw that his servants were whispering together, he perceived that the child was dead, and David said to his servants, “Is the child dead?” They said, “He is dead.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David rose from the ground, washed, anointed himself, and changed his clothes. He went into the house of the Lord and worshiped; he then went to his own house, and when he asked, they set food before him, and he ate.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then his servants said to him, “What is this thing that you have done? You fasted and wept for the child while it was alive, but when the child died, you rose and ate food.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said, “While the child was still alive, I fasted and wept, for I said, ‘Who knows? The Lord may be gracious to me, and the child may live.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But now he is dead; why should I fast? Can I bring him back again? I shall go to him, but he will not return to me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David consoled his wife Bathsheba and went to her and lay with her, and she bore a son, and he named him Solomon. The Lord loved him
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and sent a message by the prophet Nathan, so he named him Jedidiah because of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Joab fought against Rabbah of the Ammonites and took the royal city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joab sent messengers to David and said, “I have fought against Rabbah; moreover, I have taken the water city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now, then, gather the rest of the people together, encamp against the city, and take it, lest I myself take the city and it is called by my name.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David gathered all the people together and went to Rabbah and fought against it and took it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He took the crown of Milcom from his head; the weight of it was a talent of gold, and in it was a precious stone, and it was placed on David’s head. He also brought forth the spoil of the city, a very great amount.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He brought out the people who were in it and set them to work with saws and iron picks and iron axes or sent them to the brickworks. Thus he did to all the cities of the Ammonites. Then David and all the people returned to Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Some time passed. David’s son Absalom had a beautiful sister whose name was Tamar, and David’s son Amnon fell in love with her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Amnon was so tormented that he made himself ill because of his sister Tamar, for she was a virgin, and it seemed impossible to Amnon to do anything to her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Amnon had a friend whose name was Jonadab, the son of David’s brother Shimeah, and Jonadab was a very crafty man.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said to him, “O son of the king, why are you so haggard morning after morning? Will you not tell me?” Amnon said to him, “I love Tamar, my brother Absalom’s sister.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jonadab said to him, “Lie down on your bed and pretend to be ill, and when your father comes to see you, say to him, ‘Let my sister Tamar come and give me something to eat and prepare the food in my sight, so that I may see it and eat it from her hand.’ ”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Amnon lay down and pretended to be ill, and when the king came to see him, Amnon said to the king, “Please let my sister Tamar come and make a couple of cakes in my sight, so that I may eat from her hand.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David sent home to Tamar, saying, “Go to your brother Amnon’s house and prepare food for him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Tamar went to her brother Amnon’s house, where he was lying down. She took dough, kneaded it, made cakes in his sight, and baked the cakes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then she took the pan and set them before him, but he refused to eat. Amnon said, “Send out everyone from me.” So everyone went out from him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Amnon said to Tamar, “Bring the food into the chamber so that I may eat from your hand.” So Tamar took the cakes she had made and brought them into the chamber to Amnon her brother.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when she brought them near him to eat, he took hold of her and said to her, “Come, lie with me, my sister.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She answered him, “No, my brother, do not force me, for such a thing is not done in Israel; do not do anything so vile!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As for me, where could I carry my shame? And as for you, you would be as one of the scoundrels in Israel. Now therefore, I beg you, speak to the king, for he will not withhold me from you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But he would not listen to her, and being stronger than she, he forced her and lay with her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Amnon was seized with a very great loathing for her; indeed, his loathing was even greater than the lust he had felt for her. Amnon said to her, “Get out!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But she said to him, “No, my brother, for this wrong in sending me away is greater than the other that you did to me.” But he would not listen to her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He called the young man who served him and said, “Put this woman out of my presence and bolt the door after her.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (Now she was wearing an ornamented robe with sleeves, for this is how the virgin daughters of the king were clothed in earlier times.) So his servant put her out and bolted the door after her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Tamar put ashes on her head and tore the long robe that she was wearing; she put her hand on her head and went away, crying aloud as she went.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Her brother Absalom said to her, “Has Amnon your brother been with you? Be quiet for now, my sister; he is your brother; do not take this to heart.” So Tamar remained, a desolate woman, in her brother Absalom’s house.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When King David heard of all these things, he became very angry, but he would not punish his son Amnon because he loved him, for he was his firstborn.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Absalom spoke to Amnon neither good nor bad, for Absalom hated Amnon because he had raped his sister Tamar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After two full years Absalom had sheepshearers at Baal-hazor, which is near Ephraim, and Absalom invited all the king’s sons.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Absalom came to the king and said, “Your servant has sheepshearers; will the king and his servants please go with your servant?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the king said to Absalom, “No, my son, let us not all go, or else we will be burdensome to you.” He pressed him, but he would not go but gave him his blessing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Absalom said, “If not, please let my brother Amnon go with us.” The king said to him, “Why should he go with you?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Absalom pressed him until he let Amnon and all the king’s sons go with him. Absalom made a feast like a king’s feast.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Absalom commanded his servants, “Watch when Amnon’s heart is merry with wine, and when I say to you, ‘Strike Amnon,’ then kill him. Do not be afraid; have I not myself commanded you? Be courageous and valiant.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the servants of Absalom did to Amnon as Absalom had commanded. Then all the king’s sons rose, and each mounted his mule and fled.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While they were on the way, the report came to David that Absalom had killed all the king’s sons, and not one of them was left.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king rose, tore his garments, and lay on the ground, and all his servants who were standing by tore their garments.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Jonadab, the son of David’s brother Shimeah, said, “Let not my lord suppose that they have killed all the young men the king’s sons; Amnon alone is dead. This has been determined by Absalom from the day Amnon raped his sister Tamar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now, therefore, do not let my lord the king take it to heart, as if all the king’s sons were dead, for Amnon alone is dead.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Absalom fled. When the young man who kept watch looked up, he saw many people coming from the Horonaim road by the side of the mountain.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jonadab said to the king, “See, the king’s sons have come; as your servant said, so it has come about.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As soon as he had finished speaking, the king’s sons arrived and raised their voices and wept, and the king and all his servants also wept very bitterly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Absalom fled and went to Talmai son of Ammihud, king of Geshur. David mourned for his son day after day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Absalom, having fled to Geshur, stayed there three years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the heart of the king went out, yearning for Absalom, for he was now consoled over the death of Amnon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Joab son of Zeruiah perceived that the king’s mind was on Absalom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joab sent to Tekoa and brought from there a wise woman. He said to her, “Pretend to be a mourner; put on mourning garments, and do not anoint yourself with oil, but behave like a woman who has been mourning many days for the dead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Go to the king and speak to him as follows.” And Joab put the words into her mouth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the woman of Tekoa came to the king, she fell on her face to the ground and did obeisance and said, “Help, O king!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king asked her, “What is your trouble?” She answered, “Alas, I am a widow; my husband is dead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Your servant had two sons, and they fought with one another in the field; there was no one to part them, and one struck the other and killed him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now the whole family has risen against your servant. They say, ‘Give up the man who struck his brother, so that we may kill him for the life of his brother whom he murdered, even if we destroy the heir as well.’ Thus they would quench my one remaining ember and leave to my husband neither name nor remnant on the face of the earth.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king said to the woman, “Go to your house, and I will give orders concerning you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The woman of Tekoa said to the king, “On me be the guilt, my lord the king, and on my father’s house; let the king and his throne be guiltless.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king said, “If anyone says anything to you, bring him to me, and he shall never touch you again.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then she said, “Please, may the king keep the Lord your God in mind, so that the avenger of blood may kill no more and my son not be destroyed.” He said, “As the Lord lives, not one hair of your son shall fall to the ground.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the woman said, “Please let your servant speak a word to my lord the king.” He said, “Speak.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The woman said, “Why then have you planned such a thing against the people of God? For in giving this decision the king convicts himself, inasmuch as the king does not bring his banished one home again.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We must all die; we are like water spilled on the ground, which cannot be gathered up. But God will not take away a life; he will devise plans so as not to keep an outcast banished forever from his presence.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now I have come to say this to my lord the king because the people have made me afraid; your servant thought, ‘I will speak to the king; it may be that the king will perform the request of his servant.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For the king will hear and deliver his servant from the hand of the man who would cut both me and my son off from the heritage of God.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Your servant thought, ‘The word of my lord the king will set me at rest,’ for my lord the king is like the angel of God, discerning good and evil. The Lord your God be with you!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king answered the woman, “Do not withhold from me anything I ask you.” The woman said, “Let my lord the king speak.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king said, “Is the hand of Joab with you in all this?” The woman answered and said, “As surely as you live, my lord the king, one cannot turn right or left from anything that my lord the king has said. For it was your servant Joab who commanded me; it was he who put all these words into the mouth of your servant.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In order to change the course of affairs your servant Joab did this. But my lord has wisdom like the wisdom of the angel of God to know all things that are on the earth.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king said to Joab, “Very well, I grant this; go, bring back the young man Absalom.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joab prostrated himself with his face to the ground and did obeisance and blessed the king, and Joab said, “Today your servant knows that I have found favor in your sight, my lord the king, in that the king has granted the request of his servant.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Joab set off, went to Geshur, and brought Absalom to Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king said, “Let him go to his own house; he is not to come into my presence.” So Absalom went to his own house and did not come into the king’s presence.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now in all Israel there was no one to be praised so much for his beauty as Absalom; from the sole of his foot to the crown of his head there was no blemish in him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he cut the hair of his head (for at the end of every year he used to cut it; when it was heavy on him, he cut it), he weighed the hair of his head, two hundred shekels by the king’s weight.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There were born to Absalom three sons and one daughter whose name was Tamar; she was a beautiful woman.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Absalom lived two full years in Jerusalem without coming into the king’s presence.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Absalom sent for Joab to send him to the king, but Joab would not come to him. He sent a second time, but Joab would not come.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he said to his servants, “Look, Joab’s field is next to mine, and he has barley there; go and set it on fire.” So Absalom’s servants set the field on fire.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Joab rose and went to Absalom at his house and said to him, “Why have your servants set my field on fire?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Absalom answered Joab, “Look, I sent word to you. Come here that I may send you to the king with the question, ‘Why have I come from Geshur? It would be better for me to be there still.’ Now let me go into the king’s presence; if there is guilt in me, let him kill me!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Joab went to the king and told him, and he summoned Absalom. So he came to the king and prostrated himself with his face to the ground before the king, and the king kissed Absalom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After this Absalom provided for himself a chariot and horses and fifty men to run ahead of him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Absalom used to rise early and stand beside the road into the gate, and when anyone brought a suit before the king for judgment, Absalom would call out and say, “From what city are you?” When the person said, “Your servant is of such and such a tribe in Israel,”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Absalom would say, “See, your claims are good and right, but there is no one deputed by the king to hear you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Absalom would also say, “If only I were judge in the land! Then all who had a suit or cause might come to me, and I would give them justice.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Whenever people came near to do obeisance to him, he would put out his hand and take hold of them and kiss them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Thus Absalom did to every Israelite who came to the king for judgment, so Absalom stole the hearts of the people of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At the end of four years Absalom said to the king, “Please let me go to Hebron and pay the vow that I have made to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For your servant made a vow while I lived at Geshur in Aram: If the Lord will indeed bring me back to Jerusalem, then I will serve the Lord in Hebron.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king said to him, “Go in peace.” So he got up and went to Hebron.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Absalom sent secret messengers throughout all the tribes of Israel, saying, “As soon as you hear the sound of the trumpet, then shout: Absalom has become king at Hebron!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Two hundred men from Jerusalem went with Absalom; they were invited guests, and they went in innocence, knowing nothing of the matter.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While Absalom was offering the sacrifices, he sent for Ahithophel the Gilonite, David’s counselor, from his city Giloh. The conspiracy grew in strength, and the people with Absalom kept increasing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A messenger came to David, saying, “The hearts of the Israelites have gone after Absalom.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David said to all his officials who were with him at Jerusalem, “Get up! Let us flee, or there will be no escape for us from Absalom. Hurry, or he will soon overtake us, and bring disaster down upon us, and attack the city with the edge of the sword.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king’s officials said to the king, “Your servants are ready to do whatever our lord the king decides.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the king left, followed by all his household, except ten concubines whom he left behind to look after the house.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king left, followed by all the people, and they stopped at the last house.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All his officials passed by him, and all the Cherethites, and all the Pelethites, and all the six hundred Gittites who had followed him from Gath passed on before the king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king said to Ittai the Gittite, “Why are you also coming with us? Go back, and stay with the king, for you are a foreigner and also an exile from your home.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You came only yesterday, and shall I today make you wander about with us while I go wherever I can? Go back, and take your kinsfolk with you, and may the Lord show steadfast love and faithfulness to you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Ittai answered the king, “As the Lord lives and as my lord the king lives, wherever my lord the king may be, whether for death or for life, there also your servant will be.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David said to Ittai, “Go then, march on.” So Ittai the Gittite marched on, with all his men and all the little ones who were with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The whole country wept aloud as all the people passed by; the king crossed the Wadi Kidron, and all the people moved on toward the wilderness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abiathar came up, and Zadok also, with all the Levites, carrying the ark of the covenant of God. They set down the ark of God until the people had all passed out of the city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king said to Zadok, “Carry the ark of God back into the city. If I find favor in the eyes of the Lord, he will bring me back and let me see both it and the place where it stays.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if he says, ‘I take no pleasure in you,’ here I am, let him do to me what seems good to him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king also said to the priest Zadok, “Look, go back to the city in peace, you and Abiathar, with your two sons, Ahimaaz your son and Jonathan son of Abiathar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: See, I will wait at the fords of the wilderness until word comes from you to inform me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Zadok and Abiathar carried the ark of God back to Jerusalem, and they remained there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But David went up the ascent of the Mount of Olives, weeping as he went, with his head covered and walking barefoot, and all the people who were with him covered their heads and went up, weeping as they went.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David was told that Ahithophel was among the conspirators with Absalom. And David said, “O Lord, I pray you, turn the counsel of Ahithophel into foolishness.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When David came to the summit, where God was worshiped, Hushai the Archite came to meet him with his coat torn and earth on his head.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David said to him, “If you go on with me, you will be a burden to me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if you return to the city and say to Absalom, ‘I will be your servant, O king; as I have been your father’s servant in time past, so now I will be your servant,’ then you will defeat for me the counsel of Ahithophel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The priests Zadok and Abiathar will be with you there. So whatever you hear from the king’s house, tell it to the priests Zadok and Abiathar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Their two sons are with them there, Zadok’s son Ahimaaz and Abiathar’s son Jonathan, and by them you shall report to me everything you hear.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Hushai, David’s friend, came into the city just as Absalom was entering Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When David had passed a little beyond the summit, Ziba the servant of Mephibosheth met him with a couple of donkeys saddled, carrying two hundred loaves of bread, one hundred bunches of raisins, one hundred of summer fruits, and one skin of wine.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king said to Ziba, “Why have you brought these?” Ziba answered, “The donkeys are for the king’s household to ride, the bread and summer fruit are for the young men to eat, and the wine is for those to drink who faint in the wilderness.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king said, “And where is your master’s son?” Ziba said to the king, “He remains in Jerusalem, for he said, ‘Today the house of Israel will give me back my grandfather’s kingdom.’ ”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king said to Ziba, “All that belonged to Mephibosheth is now yours.” Ziba said, “I do obeisance; let me find favor in your sight, my lord the king.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When King David came to Bahurim, a man of the family of the house of Saul came out whose name was Shimei son of Gera; he came out cursing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He threw stones at David and at all the servants of King David; now all the people and all the warriors were on his right and on his left.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Shimei shouted while he cursed, “Out! Out! Murderer! Scoundrel!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord has avenged on all of you the blood of the house of Saul, in whose place you have reigned, and the Lord has given the kingdom into the hand of your son Absalom. See, disaster has overtaken you, for you are a man of blood.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Abishai son of Zeruiah said to the king, “Why should this dead dog curse my lord the king? Let me go over and take off his head.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the king said, “What have I to do with you, you sons of Zeruiah? If he is cursing because the Lord has said to him, ‘Curse David,’ who then shall say, ‘Why have you done so?’ ”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David said to Abishai and to all his servants, “My own son seeks my life; how much more now may this Benjaminite! Let him alone, and let him curse, for the Lord has bidden him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It may be that the Lord will look on my distress, and the Lord will repay me with good for this cursing of me today.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David and his men went on the road while Shimei went along on the hillside opposite him and cursed as he went, throwing stones and flinging dust at him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king and all the people who were with him arrived weary at the Jordan, and there he refreshed himself.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Absalom and all the Israelites came to Jerusalem; Ahithophel was with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Hushai the Archite, David’s friend, came to Absalom, Hushai said to Absalom, “Long live the king! Long live the king!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Absalom said to Hushai, “Is this your loyalty to your friend? Why did you not go with your friend?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hushai said to Absalom, “No, but the one whom the Lord and this people and all the Israelites have chosen, his I will be, and with him I will remain.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moreover, whom should I serve? Should it not be his son? Just as I have served your father, so I will serve you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Absalom said to Ahithophel, “Give us your counsel; what shall we do?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ahithophel said to Absalom, “Go in to your father’s concubines, the ones he has left to look after the house, and all Israel will hear that you have made yourself odious to your father, and the hands of all who are with you will be strengthened.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they pitched a tent for Absalom upon the roof, and Absalom went in to his father’s concubines in the sight of all Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now in those days the counsel that Ahithophel gave was as if one consulted the oracle of God, so all the counsel of Ahithophel was esteemed both by David and by Absalom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moreover Ahithophel said to Absalom, “Let me choose twelve thousand men, and I will set out and pursue David tonight.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will come upon him while he is weary and discouraged and throw him into a panic, and all the people who are with him will flee. I will strike down only the king,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and I will bring all the people back to you as a bride comes home to her husband. You seek the life of only one man, and all the people will be at peace.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The advice pleased Absalom and all the elders of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Absalom said, “Call Hushai the Archite also, and let us hear too what he has to say.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Hushai came to Absalom, Absalom said to him, “This is what Ahithophel has said; shall we do as he advises? If not, you tell us.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Hushai said to Absalom, “This time the counsel that Ahithophel has given is not good.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hushai continued, “You know that your father and his men are warriors and that they are enraged, like a bear robbed of her cubs in the field. Besides, your father is expert in war; he will not spend the night with the troops.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Even now he has hidden himself in one of the pits or in some other place. And when some of our troops fall at the first attack, whoever hears it will say, ‘There has been a slaughter among the troops who follow Absalom.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then even the valiant warrior whose heart is like the heart of a lion will utterly melt with fear, for all Israel knows that your father is a warrior and that those who are with him are valiant warriors.
verses.speaker: Narrator
