verses.text: But my counsel is that all Israel be gathered to you, from Dan to Beer-sheba, like the sand by the sea for multitude, and that you go to battle in person.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So we shall come upon him in whatever place he may be found, and we shall light on him as the dew falls on the ground, and he will not survive, nor will any of those with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If he withdraws into a city, then all Israel will bring ropes to that city, and we shall drag it into the valley until not even a pebble is to be found there.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Absalom and all the men of Israel said, “The counsel of Hushai the Archite is better than the counsel of Ahithophel.” For the Lord had ordained to defeat the good counsel of Ahithophel, so that the Lord might bring ruin on Absalom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Hushai said to the priests Zadok and Abiathar, “Thus and so did Ahithophel counsel Absalom and the elders of Israel, and thus and so I have counseled.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Therefore send quickly and tell David, ‘Do not lodge tonight at the fords of the wilderness, but by all means cross over, lest the king and all the people who are with him be swallowed up.’ ”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jonathan and Ahimaaz were waiting at En-rogel; a female slave used to go and tell them, and they would go and tell King David, for they could not risk being seen entering the city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But a young man saw them and told Absalom, so both of them went away quickly and came to the house of a man at Bahurim who had a well in his courtyard, and they went down into it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The man’s wife took a covering, stretched it over the well’s mouth, and spread out grain on it, and nothing was known of it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Absalom’s servants came to the woman at the house, they said, “Where are Ahimaaz and Jonathan?” The woman said to them, “They have crossed over the brook of water.” And when they had searched and could not find them, they returned to Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After they had gone, the men came up out of the well and went and told King David. They said to David, “Go and cross the water quickly, for thus and so has Ahithophel counseled against you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David and all the people who were with him set out and crossed the Jordan; by daybreak not one was left who had not crossed the Jordan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Ahithophel saw that his counsel was not followed, he saddled his donkey and went off home to his own city. He set his house in order and hanged himself; he died and was buried in the tomb of his father.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David came to Mahanaim, while Absalom crossed the Jordan with all the men of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Absalom had set Amasa over the army in the place of Joab. Amasa was the son of a man named Ithra the Ishmaelite, who had married Abigal daughter of Nahash, sister of Zeruiah, Joab’s mother.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Israelites and Absalom encamped in the land of Gilead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When David came to Mahanaim, Shobi son of Nahash from Rabbah of the Ammonites, and Machir son of Ammiel from Lo-debar, and Barzillai the Gileadite from Rogelim
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: brought beds, basins, and earthen vessels, wheat, barley, meal, parched grain, beans and lentils,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: honey and curds, sheep, and cheese from the herd, for David and the people with him to eat, for they said, “The troops are hungry and weary and thirsty in the wilderness.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David mustered the men who were with him and set over them commanders of thousands and commanders of hundreds.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And David sent forth the army: one third under the command of Joab; one third under the command of Abishai son of Zeruiah, Joab’s brother; and one third under the command of Ittai the Gittite. The king said to the men, “I myself will also go out with you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the men said, “You shall not go out. For if we flee, they will not care about us. If half of us die, they will not care about us. But you are worth ten thousand of us; therefore it is better that you send us help from the city.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king said to them, “Whatever seems best to you I will do.” So the king stood at the side of the gate, while all the army marched out by hundreds and by thousands.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king ordered Joab and Abishai and Ittai, saying, “Deal gently for my sake with the young man Absalom.” And all the people heard when the king gave orders to all the commanders concerning Absalom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the army went out into the field against Israel, and the battle was fought in the forest of Ephraim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The men of Israel were defeated there by the servants of David, and the slaughter there was great on that day, twenty thousand men.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The battle spread over the face of all the country, and the forest claimed more victims that day than the sword.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Absalom happened to meet the servants of David. Absalom was riding on his mule, and the mule went under the thick branches of a great oak. His head caught fast in the oak, and he was left hanging between heaven and earth, while the mule that was under him went on.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A man saw it and told Joab, “I saw Absalom hanging in an oak.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joab said to the man who told him, “What, you saw him! Why then did you not strike him there to the ground? I would have been glad to give you ten pieces of silver and a belt.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the man said to Joab, “Even if I felt in my hand the weight of a thousand pieces of silver, I would not raise my hand against the king’s son, for in our hearing the king commanded you and Abishai and Ittai, saying, ‘For my sake protect the young man Absalom!’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the other hand, if I had dealt treacherously against his life (and there is nothing hidden from the king), then you yourself would have stood aloof.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joab said, “I will not waste time like this with you.” He took three spears in his hand and thrust them into the heart of Absalom while he was still alive in the oak.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And ten young men, Joab’s armor-bearers, surrounded Absalom and struck him and killed him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Joab sounded the trumpet, and the troops came back from pursuing Israel, for Joab restrained the troops.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They took Absalom, threw him into a great pit in the forest, and raised over him a very great heap of stones. Meanwhile all the Israelites fled to their homes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Absalom in his lifetime had taken and set up for himself a pillar that is in the King’s Valley, for he said, “I have no son to keep my name in remembrance.” He called the pillar by his own name; it is called Absalom’s Monument to this day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Ahimaaz son of Zadok said, “Let me run and carry tidings to the king that the Lord has delivered him from the power of his enemies.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joab said to him, “You are not to carry tidings today; you may carry tidings another day, but today you shall not do so because the king’s son is dead.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Joab said to a Cushite, “Go, tell the king what you have seen.” The Cushite bowed before Joab and ran.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Ahimaaz son of Zadok said again to Joab, “Come what may, let me also run after the Cushite.” And Joab said, “Why will you run, my son, seeing that you have no reward for the tidings?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Come what may,” he said, “I will run.” So he said to him, “Run.” Then Ahimaaz ran by the way of the Plain and outran the Cushite.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now David was sitting between the two gates. The sentinel went up to the roof of the gate by the wall, and when he looked up he saw a man running alone.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sentinel shouted and told the king. The king said, “If he is alone, there are tidings in his mouth.” He kept coming and drew near.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the sentinel saw another man running, and the sentinel called to the gatekeeper and said, “See, another man running alone!” The king said, “He also is bringing tidings.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sentinel said, “I think the first one runs like Ahimaaz son of Zadok.” The king said, “He is a good man and comes with good tidings.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Ahimaaz cried out to the king, “All is well!” He prostrated himself before the king with his face to the ground and said, “Blessed be the Lord your God, who has delivered up the men who raised their hand against my lord the king.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king said, “Is it well with the young man Absalom?” Ahimaaz answered, “I saw a great tumult when the king’s servant Joab sent your servant, but I do not know what it was.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king said, “Turn aside, and stand here.” So he turned aside and stood still.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Cushite came, and the Cushite said, “Good tidings for my lord the king! For the Lord has vindicated you this day, delivering you from the power of all who rose up against you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king said to the Cushite, “Is it well with the young man Absalom?” The Cushite answered, “May the enemies of my lord the king and all who rise up to do you harm be like that young man.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king was deeply moved and went up to the chamber over the gate and wept, and as he went he said, “O my son Absalom, my son, my son Absalom! Would I had died instead of you, O Absalom, my son, my son!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It was told Joab, “The king is weeping and mourning for Absalom.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the victory that day was turned into mourning for all the troops, for the troops heard that day, “The king is grieving for his son.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The troops stole into the city that day as soldiers steal in who are ashamed when they flee in battle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king covered his face, and the king cried with a loud voice, “O my son Absalom, O Absalom, my son, my son!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Joab came into the house to the king and said, “Today you have covered with shame the faces of all your officers who have saved your life today, and the lives of your sons and your daughters, and the lives of your wives and your concubines,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: for love of those who hate you and for hatred of those who love you. You have made it clear today that commanders and officers are nothing to you, for I perceive that, if Absalom were alive and all of us were dead today, then you would be pleased.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So go out at once and speak kindly to your servants, for I swear by the Lord, if you do not go, not a man will stay with you this night, and this will be worse for you than any disaster that has come upon you from your youth until now.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then the king got up and took his seat in the gate. The troops were all told, “See, the king is sitting in the gate,” and all the troops came before the king.
Meanwhile, all the Israelites had fled to their homes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the people were disputing throughout all the tribes of Israel, saying, “The king delivered us from the hand of our enemies and saved us from the hand of the Philistines, and now he has fled out of the land because of Absalom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Absalom, whom we anointed over us, is dead in battle. Now therefore why do you say nothing about bringing the king back?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King David sent this message to the priests Zadok and Abiathar, “Say to the elders of Judah, ‘Why should you be the last to bring the king back to his house? The talk of all Israel has come to the king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You are my kin; you are my bone and my flesh; why then should you be the last to bring back the king?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And say to Amasa, ‘Are you not my bone and my flesh? So may God do to me and more, if you are not the commander of my army from now on, in place of Joab.’ ”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Amasa swayed the hearts of all the people of Judah as one, and they sent word to the king, “Return, both you and all your servants.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the king came back to the Jordan, and Judah came to Gilgal to meet the king and to bring him over the Jordan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Shimei son of Gera, a Benjaminite from Bahurim, hurried to come down with the people of Judah to meet King David;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: with him were a thousand people from Benjamin. And Ziba, the servant of the house of Saul, with his fifteen sons and his twenty servants, rushed down to the Jordan ahead of the king
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
while the crossing was taking place, to bring over the king’s household and to do his pleasure.
Shimei son of Gera fell down before the king as he was about to cross the Jordan
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and said to the king, “May my lord not hold me guilty or remember how your servant did wrong on the day my lord the king left Jerusalem; may the king not bear it in mind.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For your servant knows that I have sinned; therefore, see, I have come this day, the first of all the house of Joseph to come down to meet my lord the king.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abishai son of Zeruiah answered, “Shall not Shimei be put to death for this because he cursed the Lord’s anointed?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But David said, “What have I to do with you, you sons of Zeruiah, that you should today become an adversary to me? Shall anyone be put to death in Israel this day? For do I not know that I am this day king over Israel?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king said to Shimei, “You shall not die.” And the king gave him his oath.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Mephibosheth grandson of Saul came down to meet the king; he had not taken care of his feet or trimmed his beard or washed his clothes from the day the king left until the day he came back in safety.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he came from Jerusalem to meet the king, the king said to him, “Why did you not go with me, Mephibosheth?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He answered, “My lord, O king, my servant deceived me, for your servant said to him, ‘Saddle a donkey for me so that I may ride on it and go with the king.’ For your servant is lame.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He has slandered your servant to my lord the king. But my lord the king is like the angel of God; do therefore what seems good to you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For all my father’s house were doomed to death before my lord the king, but you set your servant among those who eat at your table. What further right have I, then, to appeal to the king?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king said to him, “Why speak any more of your affairs? I have decided: you and Ziba shall divide the land.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Mephibosheth said to the king, “Let him take it all, since my lord the king has arrived home safely.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Barzillai the Gileadite had come down from Rogelim; he went on with the king to the Jordan to escort him over the Jordan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Barzillai was a very aged man, eighty years old. He had provided the king with food while he stayed at Mahanaim, for he was a very wealthy man.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king said to Barzillai, “Come over with me, and I will provide for you in Jerusalem at my side.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Barzillai said to the king, “How many years have I still to live, that I should go up with the king to Jerusalem?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Today I am eighty years old; can I discern what is pleasant and what is not? Can your servant taste what he eats or what he drinks? Can I still listen to the voice of singing men and singing women? Why then should your servant be an added burden to my lord the king?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Your servant will go a little way over the Jordan with the king. Why should the king recompense me with such a reward?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Please let your servant return, so that I may die in my own town, near the graves of my father and my mother. But here is your servant Chimham; let him go over with my lord the king and do for him whatever seems good to you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king answered, “Chimham shall go over with me, and I will do for him whatever seems good to you, and all that you desire of me I will do for you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then all the people crossed over the Jordan, and the king crossed over; the king kissed Barzillai and blessed him, and he returned to his own home.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king went on to Gilgal, and Chimham went on with him; all the people of Judah, and also half the people of Israel, brought the king on his way.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then all the people of Israel came to the king and said to him, “Why have our kindred the people of Judah stolen you away and brought the king and his household over the Jordan and all David’s men with him?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the people of Judah answered the people of Israel, “Because the king is near of kin to us. Why then are you angry over this matter? Have we eaten at all at the king’s expense? Or has he given us any gift?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the people of Israel answered the people of Judah, “We have ten shares in the king, and in David also we have more than you. Why then did you despise us? Were we not the first to speak of bringing back our king?” But the words of the people of Judah were fiercer than the words of the people of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Now a scoundrel named Sheba son of Bichri, a Benjaminite, happened to be there. He sounded the trumpet and cried out,
“We have no portion in David,
no share in the son of Jesse!
Everyone to your tents, O Israel!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So all the people of Israel withdrew from David and followed Sheba son of Bichri, but the people of Judah followed their king steadfastly from the Jordan to Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David came to his house at Jerusalem, and the king took the ten concubines whom he had left to look after the house and put them in a house under guard and provided for them but did not go in to them. So they were shut up until the day of their death, living as if in widowhood.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king said to Amasa, “Call the men of Judah together to me within three days, and be here yourself.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Amasa went to summon Judah, but he delayed beyond the set time that had been appointed him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David said to Abishai, “Now Sheba son of Bichri will do us more harm than Absalom; take your lord’s servants and pursue him, or he will find fortified cities for himself and escape from us.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joab’s men went out after him, along with the Cherethites, the Pelethites, and all the warriors; they went out from Jerusalem to pursue Sheba son of Bichri.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they were at the large stone that is in Gibeon, Amasa came to meet them. Now Joab was wearing a soldier’s garment, and over it was a belt with a sword in its sheath fastened at his waist; as he went forward, it fell out.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joab said to Amasa, “Is it well with you, my brother?” And Joab took Amasa by the beard with his right hand to kiss him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But Amasa did not notice the sword in Joab’s hand; Joab struck him in the belly so that his entrails poured out on the ground, and he died. He did not strike a second blow.
Then Joab and his brother Abishai pursued Sheba son of Bichri.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And one of Joab’s men took his stand by Amasa and said, “Whoever favors Joab, and whoever is for David, let him follow Joab.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Amasa lay wallowing in his blood on the highway, and the man saw that all the people were stopping. Since he saw that all who came by him were stopping, he carried Amasa from the highway into a field and threw a garment over him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Once he was removed from the highway, all the people went on after Joab to pursue Sheba son of Bichri.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Sheba passed through all the tribes of Israel to Abel of Beth-maacah, and all the Bichrites assembled and followed him inside.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joab’s forces came and besieged him in Abel of Beth-maacah; they threw up a siege ramp against the city, and it stood against the rampart. Joab’s forces were battering the wall to break it down.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then a wise woman called from the city, “Listen! Listen! Tell Joab, ‘Come here, I want to speak to you.’ ”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He came near her, and the woman said, “Are you Joab?” He answered, “I am.” Then she said to him, “Listen to the words of your servant.” He answered, “I am listening.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then she said, “They used to say in the old days, ‘Let them inquire at Abel,’ and so they would settle a matter.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I am one of those who are peaceable and faithful in Israel; you seek to destroy a city that is a mother in Israel; why will you swallow up the heritage of the Lord?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joab answered, “Far be it from me, far be it, that I should swallow up or destroy!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That is not the case! But a man of the hill country of Ephraim called Sheba son of Bichri has lifted up his hand against King David; give him up alone, and I will withdraw from the city.” The woman said to Joab, “His head shall be thrown over the wall to you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the woman went to all the people with her wise plan. And they cut off the head of Sheba son of Bichri and threw it out to Joab. So he blew the trumpet, and they dispersed from the city, and all went to their homes, while Joab returned to Jerusalem to the king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Joab was in command of all the army of Israel; Benaiah son of Jehoiada was in command of the Cherethites and the Pelethites;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Adoram was in charge of the forced labor; Jehoshaphat son of Ahilud was the recorder;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Sheva was secretary; Zadok and Abiathar were priests;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and Ira the Jairite was also David’s priest.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now there was a famine in the days of David for three years, year after year, and David inquired of the Lord. The Lord said, “There is bloodguilt on Saul and on his house because he put the Gibeonites to death.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the king called the Gibeonites and spoke to them. (Now the Gibeonites were not of the people of Israel but of the remnant of the Amorites; although the people of Israel had sworn to spare them, Saul had tried to wipe them out in his zeal for the people of Israel and Judah.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David said to the Gibeonites, “What shall I do for you? How shall I make expiation, that you may bless the heritage of the Lord?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Gibeonites said to him, “It is not a matter of silver or gold between us and Saul or his house; neither is it for us to put anyone to death in Israel.” He said, “What do you say that I should do for you?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They said to the king, “The man who consumed us and planned to destroy us so that we should have no place in all the territory of Israel,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: let seven of his sons be handed over to us, and we will impale them before the Lord at Gibeon on the mountain of the Lord.” The king said, “I will hand them over.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the king spared Mephibosheth, the son of Saul’s son Jonathan, because of the oath of the Lord that was between them, between David and Jonathan son of Saul.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king took the two sons of Rizpah daughter of Aiah, whom she bore to Saul, Armoni and Mephibosheth; and the five sons of Merab daughter of Saul, whom she bore to Adriel son of Barzillai the Meholathite;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: he gave them into the hands of the Gibeonites, and they impaled them on the mountain before the Lord. The seven of them perished together. They were put to death in the first days of harvest, at the beginning of barley harvest.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Rizpah the daughter of Aiah took sackcloth and spread it on a rock for herself, from the beginning of harvest until rain fell on them from the heavens; she did not allow the birds of the air to come on the bodies by day or the wild animals by night.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When David was told what Rizpah daughter of Aiah, the concubine of Saul, had done,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David went and took the bones of Saul and the bones of his son Jonathan from the people of Jabesh-gilead, who had stolen them from the public square of Beth-shan, where the Philistines had hung them up, on the day the Philistines killed Saul on Gilboa.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He brought up from there the bones of Saul and the bones of his son Jonathan, and they gathered the bones of those who had been impaled.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They buried the bones of Saul and of his son Jonathan in the land of Benjamin in Zela, in the tomb of his father Kish; they did all that the king commanded. After that, God heeded supplications for the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Philistines went to war again with Israel, and David went down together with his servants. They fought against the Philistines, and David grew weary.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ishbi-benob, one of the descendants of the giants, whose spear weighed three hundred shekels of bronze and who was fitted out with new weapons, said he would kill David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Abishai son of Zeruiah came to his aid and attacked the Philistine and killed him. Then David’s men swore to him, “You shall not go out with us to battle any longer, so that you do not quench the lamp of Israel.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After this a battle took place with the Philistines at Gob; then Sibbecai the Hushathite killed Saph, who was one of the descendants of the giants.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then there was another battle with the Philistines at Gob, and Elhanan son of Jaare-oregim the Bethlehemite killed Goliath the Gittite, the shaft of whose spear was like a weaver’s beam.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was again war at Gath, where there was a man of great size who had six fingers on each hand and six toes on each foot, twenty-four in number; he, too, was descended from the giants.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he taunted Israel, Jonathan son of David’s brother Shimei killed him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These four were descended from the giants in Gath; they fell by the hands of David and his servants.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David spoke to the Lord the words of this song on the day when the Lord delivered him from the hand of all his enemies and from the hand of Saul.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He said,
“The Lord is my rock, my fortress, and my deliverer,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
my God, my rock in whom I take refuge,
my shield and the horn of my salvation,
    my stronghold and my refuge,
    my savior; you save me from violence.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I call upon the Lord, who is worthy to be praised,
    and I am saved from my enemies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For the waves of death encompassed me;
    the torrents of perdition assailed me;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
the cords of Sheol entangled me;
    the snares of death confronted me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
In my distress I called upon the Lord;
    to my God I called.
From his temple he heard my voice,
    and my cry came to his ears.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
He bowed the heavens and came down;
    thick darkness was under his feet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He rode on a cherub and flew;
    he was seen upon the wings of the wind.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He made darkness around him a canopy,
    thick clouds, a gathering of water.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Out of the brightness before him
    coals of fire flamed forth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Lord thundered from heaven;
    the Most High uttered his voice.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He sent out arrows and scattered them,
    lightning and routed them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then the channels of the sea were seen;
    the foundations of the world were laid bare
at the rebuke of the Lord,
    at the blast of the breath of his nostrils.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He reached from on high; he took me;
    he drew me out of mighty waters.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
They came upon me in the day of my calamity,
    but the Lord was my stay.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He brought me out into a broad place;
    he delivered me because he delighted in me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Lord rewarded me according to my righteousness;
    according to the cleanness of my hands he recompensed me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For I have kept the ways of the Lord
    and have not wickedly departed from my God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For all his ordinances were before me,
    and from his statutes I did not turn aside.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I was blameless before him,
    and I kept myself from guilt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Therefore the Lord has recompensed me according to my righteousness,
    according to my cleanness in his sight.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
With the loyal you show yourself loyal;
    with the blameless you show yourself blameless;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
with the pure you show yourself pure,
    and with the crooked you show yourself shrewd.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You deliver a humble people,
    but your eyes are upon the haughty to bring them down.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Indeed, you are my lamp, O Lord;
    the Lord lightens my darkness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
By you I can outrun a troop,
    and by my God I can leap over a wall.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
For who is God but the Lord?
    And who is a rock except our God?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The God who has girded me with strength
    has opened wide my path.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He made my feet like the feet of deer
    and set me secure on the heights.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He trains my hands for war,
    so that my arms can bend a bow of bronze.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You have given me the shield of your salvation,
    and your help has made me great.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You have made me stride freely,
    and my feet do not slip;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I pursued my enemies and destroyed them
    and did not turn back until they were consumed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I consumed them; I struck them down so that they did not rise;
    they fell under my feet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For you girded me with strength for the battle;
    you made my assailants sink under me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You made my enemies turn their backs to me,
    those who hated me, and I destroyed them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They looked, but there was no one to save them;
    they cried to the Lord, but he did not answer them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I beat them fine like the dust of the earth;
    I crushed them and stamped them down like the mire of the streets.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
Foreigners came cringing to me;
    as soon as they heard of me, they obeyed me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Foreigners lost heart
    and came trembling out of their strongholds.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Lord lives! Blessed be my rock,
    and exalted be my God, the rock of my salvation,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
the God who gave me vengeance
    and brought down peoples under me,
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
For this I will extol you, O Lord, among the nations
    and sing praises to your name.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He is a tower of salvation for his king
    and shows steadfast love to his anointed,
    to David and his descendants forever.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Now these are the last words of David:
The oracle of David, son of Jesse,
    the oracle of the man whom God exalted,
the anointed of the God of Jacob,
    the favorite of the Strong One of Israel:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The spirit of the Lord speaks through me;
    his word is upon my tongue.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The God of Israel has spoken;
    the Rock of Israel has said to me:
“One who rules over people justly,
    ruling in the fear of God,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
is like the light of morning,
    like the sun rising on a cloudless morning,
    gleaming from the rain on the grassy land.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Is not my house like this with God?
    For he has made with me an everlasting covenant,
    ordered in all things and secure.
Will he not cause to prosper
    all my help and my desire?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But the godless are all like thorns that are thrown away,
    for they cannot be picked up with the hand;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
to touch them one uses an iron bar
    or the shaft of a spear.
    And they are entirely consumed in fire on the spot.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These are the names of the warriors whom David had: Josheb-basshebeth a Tahchemonite; he was chief of the Three; he wielded his spear against eight hundred whom he killed at one time.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Next to him among the three warriors was Eleazar son of Dodo son of Ahohi. He was with David when they defied the Philistines who were gathered there for battle. The Israelites withdrew,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: but he stood his ground. He struck down the Philistines until his arm grew weary, though his hand clung to the sword. The Lord brought about a great victory that day. Then the people came back to him—but only to strip the dead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Next to him was Shammah son of Agee the Hararite. The Philistines gathered together at Lehi, where there was a plot of ground full of lentils, and the army fled from the Philistines.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But he took his stand in the middle of the plot, defended it, and killed the Philistines, and the Lord brought about a great victory.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Toward the beginning of harvest three of the thirty chiefs went down to join David at the cave of Adullam while a band of Philistines was encamped in the valley of Rephaim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David was then in the stronghold, and the garrison of the Philistines was then at Bethlehem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David said longingly, “Oh, that someone would give me water to drink from the well of Bethlehem that is by the gate!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the three warriors broke through the camp of the Philistines, drew water from the well of Bethlehem that was by the gate, and brought it to David. But he would not drink of it; he poured it out to the Lord,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: for he said, “The Lord forbid that I should do this. Can I drink the blood of the men who went at the risk of their lives?” Therefore he would not drink it. The three warriors did these things.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Abishai son of Zeruiah, the brother of Joab, was chief of the Thirty. With his spear he fought against three hundred men and killed them and won a name beside the Three.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He was the most renowned of the Thirty and became their commander, but he did not attain to the Three.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Benaiah son of Jehoiada was a valiant warrior from Kabzeel, a doer of great deeds; he struck down two sons of Ariel of Moab. He also went down and killed a lion in a pit on a day when snow had fallen.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And he killed an Egyptian, a handsome man. The Egyptian had a spear in his hand, but Benaiah went against him with a staff, snatched the spear out of the Egyptian’s hand, and killed him with his own spear.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Such were the things Benaiah son of Jehoiada did and won a name beside the three warriors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He was renowned among the Thirty, but he did not attain to the Three. And David put him in charge of his bodyguard.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Among the Thirty were Asahel brother of Joab; Elhanan son of Dodo of Bethlehem;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Shammah of Harod; Elika of Harod;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Helez the Paltite; Ira son of Ikkesh of Tekoa;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abiezer of Anathoth; Mebunnai the Hushathite;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Zalmon the Ahohite; Maharai of Netophah;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Heleb son of Baanah of Netophah; Ittai son of Ribai of Gibeah of the Benjaminites;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Benaiah of Pirathon; Hiddai of the wadis of Gaash;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abi-albon the Arbathite; Azmaveth of Bahurim;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Eliahba of Shaalbon; the sons of Jashen: Jonathan
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: son of Shammah the Hararite; Ahiam son of Sharar the Hararite;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Eliphelet son of Ahasbai of Maacah; Eliam son of Ahithophel the Gilonite;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hezro of Carmel; Paarai the Arbite;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Igal son of Nathan of Zobah; Bani the Gadite;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Zelek the Ammonite; Naharai of Beeroth, the armor-bearer of Joab son of Zeruiah;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ira the Ithrite; Gareb the Ithrite;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Uriah the Hittite—thirty-seven in all.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Again the anger of the Lord was kindled against Israel, and he incited David against them, saying, “Go, count the people of Israel and Judah.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the king said to Joab and the commanders of the army who were with him, “Go through all the tribes of Israel, from Dan to Beer-sheba, and take a census of the people, so that I may know how many there are.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Joab said to the king, “May the Lord your God increase the number of the people a hundredfold while the eyes of my lord the king can still see it! But why does my lord the king want to do this?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the king’s word prevailed against Joab and the commanders of the army. So Joab and the commanders of the army went out from the presence of the king to take a census of the people of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They crossed the Jordan and began from Aroer and from the city that is in the middle of the valley, toward Gad and on to Jazer.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they came to Gilead and to Kadesh in the land of the Hittites, and they came to Dan, and from Dan they went around to Sidon
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and came to the fortress of Tyre and to all the cities of the Hivites and Canaanites, and they went out to the Negeb of Judah at Beer-sheba.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So when they had gone through all the land, they came back to Jerusalem at the end of nine months and twenty days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joab reported to the king the number of those who had been recorded: in Israel there were eight hundred thousand soldiers able to draw the sword, and those of Judah were five hundred thousand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But afterward, David was stricken to the heart because he had numbered the people. David said to the Lord, “I have sinned greatly in what I have done. But now, O Lord, I pray you, take away the guilt of your servant, for I have done very foolishly.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When David rose in the morning, the word of the Lord came to the prophet Gad, David’s seer, saying,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Go and say to David: Thus says the Lord: Three things I offer you; choose one of them, and I will do it to you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Gad came to David and told him; he asked him, “Shall seven years of famine come to you on your land? Or will you flee three months before your foes while they pursue you? Or shall there be three days’ pestilence in your land? Now consider and decide what answer I shall return to the one who sent me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David said to Gad, “I am in great distress; let us fall into the hand of the Lord, for his mercy is great, but let me not fall into human hands.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the Lord sent a pestilence on Israel from that morning until the appointed time, and seventy thousand of the people died, from Dan to Beer-sheba.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when the angel stretched out his hand toward Jerusalem to destroy it, the Lord relented concerning the evil and said to the angel who was bringing destruction among the people, “It is enough; now stay your hand.” The angel of the Lord was standing by the threshing floor of Araunah the Jebusite. David looked up and saw the angel of the Lord standing between earth and heaven and in his hand a drawn sword stretched out over Jerusalem. Then David and the elders, clothed in sackcloth, fell on their faces.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When David saw the angel who was destroying the people, he said to the Lord, “I alone have sinned, and I, the shepherd, have done evil, but these sheep, what have they done? Let your hand, I pray, be against me and against my father’s house.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That day Gad came to David and said to him, “Go up and erect an altar to the Lord on the threshing floor of Araunah the Jebusite.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Following Gad’s instructions, David went up, as the Lord had commanded.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Araunah looked down, he saw the king and his servants coming toward him, and Araunah went out and prostrated himself before the king with his face to the ground.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Araunah said, “Why has my lord the king come to his servant?” David said, “To buy the threshing floor from you in order to build an altar to the Lord, so that the plague may be averted from the people.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Araunah said to David, “Let my lord the king take and offer up what seems good to him; here are the oxen for the burnt offering and the threshing sledges and the yokes of the oxen for the wood.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All this, O king, Araunah gives to the king.” And Araunah said to the king, “May the Lord your God respond favorably to you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the king said to Araunah, “No, but I will buy them from you for a price; I will not offer burnt offerings to the Lord my God that cost me nothing.” So David bought the threshing floor and the oxen for fifty shekels of silver.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David built there an altar to the Lord and offered burnt offerings and offerings of well-being. So the Lord answered his supplication for the land, and the plague was averted from Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator
